abstract.text: New and recent results on Supersymmetry searches are shown for the ATLAS and the CMS experiments. Analyses with about 36 fb −1 are considered for searches concerning light squarks and gluinos, direct pair production of 3 rd generation squarks, electroweak production of charginos, neutralinos, sleptons, R-parity violating scenarios and long-lived particles.

body_text.text: Introduction

Supersymmetry (or SUSY) 1,2,3,4 is one of the most studied and favoured extensions of the Standard Model (SM), which postulates that for every particle in the SM there exists a supersymmetric partner (or sparticle), differing by a half unit of spin from their SM counterparts, with the squarks (q) being the scalar partners to the SM quarks and the gluinos (g) the fermionic partners to the SM gluons.

If sparticles exist at the TeV scale, they can be accessed at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) presently running at CERN (Geneva), whose center-of-mass energy has been increased from 7-8 TeV (with about 25 fb −1 collected during Run 1 in 2011-12) to 13 TeV (with 36 fb −1 collected during Run 2 in 2015-16 and additional statistics to be recorded and analyzed in 2017).

SUSY presents many advantages since it can solve a number of still open questions in the SM, by providing a solution to the hierarchy problem, by suggesting the lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP) as a possible candidate for Dark Matter in R-Parity a conserving (RPC) models and by allowing gauge coupling unification at high energies, which is not possible in the SM at any scale.

a R-parity is defined for each (s)particle as R = (−1) 3(B−L)+2S , where B is the barionic number, L is the leptonic number and S is the spin. R is +1 for SM particles and −1 for their SUSY partners. This work concentrates on an overview of results obtained in SUSY searches by the ATLAS 5 and the CMS 6 experiments running at the LHC. Many models predicting sparticles observable at the LHC have been developed, ranging from easy-to-observe models with clear signatures and large cross sections to models with very low signal cross sections that are difficult to distinguish from the relevant SM backgrounds. The cross sections of the expected SUSY production mechanisms are shown in Fig. 1 as functions of the produced sparticles. The represented colored particle cross sections are from nll-fast 7 and evaluated at √ s = 8 TeV and 13 TeV, the electroweak pure higgsino cross sections are from prospino 8 and evaluated at √ s = 8 TeV and 14 TeV. Each of the analyses presented here uses selections on various observables in order to enhance signals with respect to SM background. Signal regions (SRs) are defined using Monte Carlo (MC) simulation of the signal and of the SM processes, suitable control regions (CRs) are used to quantify each background source, and validation regions (VRs) are defined and exploited to test the descriptions provided by such estimates.
Inclusive squark and gluino searches

ATLAS and CMS have optimized a large number of analyses to search for simplified scenarios in whichgg,qq andqg pairs are produced. As an example, CMS searches for fully hadronic final states 9 rely on a huge number of SRs, defined according to requirements on the number of (b-)jets in the event and on other variables, such as the missing transverse energy (E miss T ) and the sum of jets transverse momentum p T (H T ). As shown in Fig. 2, the observed and expected SM event yields compare very well for all the considered SRs. Also the SUSY searches performed by ATLAS on decays with no leptons in the final state 10 have shown no significant excess of events with respect to the SM expectation, as the largest significance measured in a SR corresponds to only 2.14 standard deviations.   Searches with 1, 2 or more isolated leptons in the final state present the advantage of removing the SM multijet background from the SRs. As an example, in Fig. 3 the event yield is shown for ATLAS searches 11 with two same-sign (or three) leptons in the final state. Owing to their special topology, the SRs are almost SM background free and the main limitation in the analysis is given by the reduced statistics. In thegg simplified RPC models considered, the hypothesis of gluinos with masses up to 1.87 TeV is excluded in scenarios with a lightχ . After combining a collection of different analyses targeting SUSY strong production, the resulting exclusion contours from both ATLAS ( Fig. 4) and CMS ( Fig. 5) with about 36 fb −1 are obtained and presented in the m(g) − m(χ 0 1 ) plane. Compared to Run 1, exclusion limits are becoming more and more stringent on the mass of gluinos and of 1 st and 2 nd generation squarks, and for the first time the sensitivity on masses has reached values beyond 2 TeV.

Electroweak production of sparticles

Supersymmetry can be produced via the electroweak interaction, the direct pair production of charginos and neutralinos being the dominant mode of sparticles production at the LHC in the case in which the SUSY partners of the gluon and of the quarks have a mass heavier than 3-4 TeV. A huge variety of signatures is tested, mainly exploiting the multi-lepton nature of the final states.

The statistical combination of results for electroweak production searches is reported in Fig. 9 for all the channels investigated by ATLAS and in Fig. 10 for thẽ χ 0 2χ ± 1 channel. For decays via W , Z and H bosons, the sensitivity is up to ∼ 600 GeV, while it exceeds 1 TeV for decays via sleptons 13 .

body_text.text: In SUSY there is no theoretical reason why R-parity shouldn't be violated (thus bringing to RPV scenarios). Moreover, whenever mass states are almost degenerate, long-lived particles may exist (for instance in split SUSY and gauge mediated SUSY breaking models).
Searches with one lepton and multi-jet

body_text.section: Searches with one lepton and multi-jet
body_text.text: The examples of RPV analyses shown here are carried out by looking for one isolated lepton (p T > 20 GeV) and at least four jets in the final state, together with limited E miss T . In Fig. 11 results provided by CMS 15 are shown for gluino pair production in a benchmark minimal-flavour-violating model in which gluinos promptly decay to quarks t, b and s; gluino masses are excluded at 95% CL for values below 1.61   TeV. In the case of ATLAS 14 , near fully data-driven background estimations are performed, showing that tt and W /Z+jets are the dominant source of background. The analysis is based on a model-dependent multi-bin fit which considers both jets and b-jets multiplicities. No significant excess of events is found and lower limits on masses have been set: as shown in Fig. 12, gluino masses are excluded at 95 % CL in a range of values between 1.65 and 2.10 TeV, depending on the LSP mass.
Long-lived particles

Among the various searches for long-lived massive particles, final states with large missing transverse momentum and at least one high-mass displaced vertex with five or more tracks are looked for by ATLAS in the context of split SUSY 16 . The considered model foresees very high-mass squarks and a light gluino (at a mass accessible at the LHC) which decaysg → qqχ 0 1 very slowly as it proceeds via a highly virtual squark. The gluino is expected to hadronise and form a bound colour singlet state with SM particles known as an R-hadrons 17 . In Fig. 13 the exclusion limits on the gluino mass are represented as a function of the lifetime in the hypothesis of a 100 GeV neutralino, with masses reaching roughly 2000 to 2300 GeV and lifetimes between 0.02 and 10 ns.
Conclusions

LHC has performed brilliantly during Run 2, collecting about 36 fb −1 of data in years 2015 and 2016, at √ s = 13 TeV. This has allowed ATLAS and CMS experiments to carry out a wide variety of SUSY searches, for which still no significant deviation from the Standard Model has been observed. In particular, progresses have been shown regarding searches for strongly produced squarks and gluinos, third generation squarks, direct electroweak production and R-parity violating scenarios. Excluded mass ranges have been extended with respect to LHC Run 1, as they have reached approximately 2 TeV for gluinos, more than 1 TeV for top and     bottom squarks and more than 500 GeV for charginos and neutralinos. Much more data collected at √ s = 13 TeV in 2017 will enrich the full dataset of Run 2, thus hopefully bringing to new encouraging results on a wide range of SUSY analyses.

In Fig. 14 and in Fig. 15 a compact representation of the mass limits on sparticles is shown for the ATLAS and for the CMS experiments, respectively, concerning a broad list of different possible scenarios of SUSY production.
